en: The word ‘jeans’ comes from the cotton pants worn by “Genes,” the local term for Genoan sailors
The average American owns 7 pairs of blue jeans
After the 2nd century BC, in Rome respectable women wore stolas and prostitutes were required to wear a toga
The four major fashion capitals of the world are New York, London, Milan, and Paris. Each city holds fashion shows twice, in February and September
It was not acceptable for women to wear shorts in public until World War 2
The first fashion magazine was published in Germany in 1586
American households spend about 3.8% of their income on clothing, which equates to about $1,700 per person
The price of clothing has decreased by 8.5% since 1992, even when adjusted for inflation
Over a lifetime, an American woman will spend $125,000 on clothes.  3,000 items - 271 pairs of shoes, 185 dresses, and 145 bags
The five most common clothing materials are linen, cotton, polyester, and rayon
Cotton is the most widely used clothing material, but it only became common in mid-1800s
Evidence for the first clothes dates somewhere between 100,000 to 500,000 years ago
Simple needles made out of animal bone first appeared about 30,000 years ago
The bikini was named after the island Bikini Atoll, where the US military was testing its bombs in World War 2
Women’s nominal clothing sizes have increased in physical size over the years in a phenomenon known as “vanity sizing”
A size 8 dress with a 32-inch bust (81 cm) in 1967 is now considered a size 0 today
10-25% of Western women don’t wear a bra, and 75-85% of women who do wear an incorrect size
Men’s shirts button on the right, and women’s on the left
Both the pencil skirt and the A-line skirt were designed by Frenchman Christian Dior, who is singlehandedly credited with inspiring 1950s fashion
Children dressed identically to adults until the mid-1800s, when the concept of children’s clothing took off
What Americans consider “tuxedos” are called “dinner jackets” in Great Britain, as the word tuxedo itself refers to the white version of the suit jacket in British English
Dresses and skirts are commonly seen as women’s clothing in the West, but in other parts of the world, men wear them as frequently as women do
More than 2 billion t-shirts are sold each year
A person’s social rank and profession in the Medieval Ages was represented by the color of their clothing
In Rome, purple clothing was exclusively reserved for emperors and magistrates
The earliest known shoes are sandals that date back to approximately 7,000 B.C.
In Arab culture, shoes are considered dirty because they touch the ground and cover the lowest part of the body, the foot
The difference between two nominal clothing sizes is approximately ten to fifteen pounds
Standard women’s clothes are designed to fit women between 5’4 and 5’8 tall
One silk cocoon produces an average of 600 to 900 meters of silk filaments, but it takes four to eight pieces to make one strand of silk thread
Eyeliner" became popular after its discovery in King Tutankhamun’s tomb in the 1920s
It was once taboo to wear black unless one was in mourning
Until around the beginning of the 20th century, Chinese culture regarded small feet as beautiful, and it was a common practice to bind women’s feet
The fashion industry generates an average revenue of $20 billion each year
A Sneakerhead is someone who collects shoes
Nowadays, kimonos are worn only in very formal occasions in Japan except by sumo wrestlers
For all the hoopla made about Fashion Week, the average fashion show is only about 10 minutes long
Vintage clothing refers to clothing made between 20 and 100 years ago
Retro refers to recently made clothing that is designed to resemble the style of another period
It became more socially acceptable for women to wear shorts during World War 2, which introduced fabric rationing and forced women to take on more masculine jobs
The skirt is the second oldest piece of clothing, outdated only by the loincloth
People who dress like the boss are more likely to be appointed and get promoted quicker
Men are more likely to approach a women for a date if she is wearing red
Women dress more provocatively when ovulating i.e. when at their most fertile
Nine out of ten women own at least one item of clothing they have never worn. This is true of only a third of men
Wearing clothes of one colour blurs the dividing lines and makes the body look slimmer
People stand further away from others who wear dated or unfashionable dress
Women are twice as likely to wear jeans when depressed than when happy
Provocatively dressed women are judged as being less competent than those who cover up
Patients put more trust in a doctor who wears a white coat
A man in a tailor-made suit is thought to be more confident and more trustworthy than a man in an off-the-peg suit
The human eye takes longer to travel across patterned fabrics, this makes the body appear larger
People think they are physically stronger when wearing a Superman t-shirt
A female job candidate who is dressed in a masculine style is more likely to get appointed than one who is over-feminised
Women perform worse on a maths test if wearing a swimsuit than in a sweater
Women are twice as likely as men to own more then ten pairs of shoes
Dress sense is what men notice first in a woman (before face and body)
Offenders receive a harsher sentence in court if they are wearing black
Dressing in a uniform associated with brutality unleashes aggressive behaviours
People are more willing to give money to someone whose dress style resembles their own
Men check themselves and your clothes in a mirror or reflection twice as often as women
A wide shoulder line creates a visual illusion that offsets wide hips
After trying on clothing men are more than twice as likely as women to buy
Clothes in the future will be able to transmit a physical hug
Choosing the right clothes can make a person less anxious and less depressed
Napoleon Bonaparte ordered that all his soldiers wear buttons on their sleeves, because he was tired of watching them wiping their running noses on their jackets
Umbrellas weren’t invented to keep the rain off, they were invented for protection from the sun
The high heel wasn’t invented to make the ladies look sexy, it was invented to stop men falling off their horses
Louis Vuitton allegedly burns its old bags to keep the brand’s complete exclusivity
Everything about the Stella McCartney label is ethical, even the exclusive shopping bags which are made out of corn and are 100% biodegradable
Guinness World Records cites Gucci as producing the world’s most expensive jeans. Gucci Genius Jeans cost $3,134
For a limited period Christian Louboutin produced shoes with blue soles so brides could wear something blue on their wedding day
Chanel’s famous 2.55 bag takes its name from the date it was invented, February 1955
Michael Kors designed his first piece of clothing aged five. It was his mother’s wedding dress
Christian Dior was a strong believer in psychics and would visit one to determine which day would be best to show his latest collection
Aprons were once stylish, partly due to the then popular play The Marriage of Figaro, whose story goes about servants
Second-hand clothing was pretty much normal among the wealthy people
Most of French fashion traditions were lost in the Revolution. Napoleon eventually brought the glamour of fashion back in 1804
“Bra” emerged as a cool new slang word among young women in 1930s
Pajamas, pyjamas, PJs, jimjams or jammies pretty much refer to the same thing
In 1870s, chemical dyes were introduced for underwear, offering the full variety of colours
In the U.S., slave girls used grape vines to make their own crinoline hoops for their Sunday dresses
Until 19th century, men’s shirts were considered to be underwear
Hobble skirts were so narrow under the knees that walking in one was not an easy task
Nightclothes were first fashioned in 16th century. Until then, people would sleep in day clothes or naked
Queen Elizabeth I ordered that all women should wear hats on Sunday
Réard declared that a real bikini could be “pulled through a wedding ring.”
In the 1960s, Rudi Gernreich came up with monokini, a swimsuit of one piece with a completely exposed top
Barbie’s first outfit was a black-and-white striped one-piece swimsuit
Star Wars princess Leia’s bikini is thought to be the most famous bikini in the world
Giorgio Armani is not an approved Haute Couture designer
Surprisingly, in fashion industry there are more men at the executive level than women
“Haute couture” is French style for “elegant sewing”
It usually takes from 150 to 350 hours to make a custom made dress, which could cost up to $100,000
Only 2,000 women in the world (mostly from the U.S.) buy couture clothes
Catherine de Medici designed a corset that narrowed the waist to 33 cm (13 inches)
Corsets were first worn outside of clothing, like in the national costumes of Bavaria
In 1914, Mary Phelps created the first “modern” bra, using couple of handkerchiefs
In the 1920s, women would press down their chests to achieve the then-popular flat-chest look
Ida Rosenthal introduced the cup system (A, B, C, D)
Average woman in the Western world owns six bras
People who dress like the boss are more likely to be appointed and get promoted quicker.
Men are more likely to approach a women for a date if she is wearing red and vice versa.
People show more mental agility when wearing a white coat they believe is a doctor's.
A third of the men have at least one piece of clothing that they have never worn.
Runners are more likely to greet other runners who are wearing similar kit
For men, jeans are casual clothes, men go wearing the same jeans to work and to a bar with friends.
Men who wear gray coats often are artists.
If a student (man) wears shorts for a math test, then he is confident of his knowledge.
Diagonal lines placed on the body in the form of clothing detail or fabric create an illusion of a slimmer body
Men usually have 3 pairs of shoes. For work, sports and beach.
If a man wears shoes, socks play an important role in his suit, no less important than a tie.
Women have an average figure of pairs of shoes equal to 15. The ideal figure is 30, a pair of shoes for each day of the month.

If dressed in uniform in everyday life (and uniform is associated with cruelty) - this leads to aggressive behavior.
People are more willing to give money to someone whose dress style resembles their own.
Clothes in the future will be able to transmit a physical hug.
Unknown finnish company Karhu was first to put three stripes on the side of a sneaker. And then the emblem was sold to Adidas for 1600 euros.
The first pair of Levi’s was sold in 1856 for approximately $6 worth of gold dust
Steve Jobs’ go-to trainer was the New Balance 991. The perfect sneaker to go with your black rollneck.
French cuffs aren’t actually french - it is british invention. French cuffs were designed to fasten easily at the appropriate length with the excess material folded.
According to astronaut Chris Hadfield, there’s no need to do laundry in space Instead, dirty clothes are tossed outside and incinerated by the Earth’s atmosphere.
The first pair of Dr. Martens boots was made from tyres. Dr Klaus Märten broke his ankle skiing so he created a soft-leather padded sole from tyres as a more comfortable alternative to army boots.
The YKK on zips stands for ‘Yoshido Kogyo Kabushikikaisha’. Which is the biggest zip company in the world.
Men didn’t wear underwear until the 17th century.
Abercrombie & Fitch" offered to pay Jersey Shore Mike to stop wearing their clothes. Apparently they think that this can put a gap in sales.
Lacoste’s embroidered crocodile was one of the first designer logos
Сrocodile "Lacoste" was manufactured and patented in 1933. Have that "Chanel".
Prince Edward VII first wore a dinner suit. Tailless blue silk smoking jacket was the first to be worn as eveningwear, and was made by Savile Row tailors Henry Poole and Co.
Polo players invented buttoned-down shirt collars. Trying to hook a mallet on horseback is difficult enough without a collar.
Men’s and women’s clothes have buttons on opposite sides. It's made especially for women to make it easier for them to dress.
High heels were first worn by men. It was noblemen of the 16th century. These were seen as a sign of wealth and status, giving us the phrase ‘well-heeled’.
The Mackintosh coat was created by a Scottish chemist Charles Macintosh. To produce the world’s first waterproof coat in 1823.
The perforations on brogues were originally intended to let water escape. For example, during the rain.
Gingham is of Malaysian origin. The name originates from the word "genggang", which roughly translates to ‘separate’.
It was a trend during the Renaissance to shave off your eyebrows.
Pocket squares were once used for handkerchiefs. Now it's just fashion, handerchiefs are kept in pants.
Handkerchiefs appeared in the 14th century
The sailor and inventor Paul Sperry designed protections for soles after watching his dog move on wet surfaces.
Shoes with perforation designed to drain water. Therefore it is not only fashionable but also useful.
Beau Brummell hated court costumes for men, since he was a graduate of the elite English college of Eton, he began to develop a modern costume.
Side ventilation holes on the suits were designed for easy landing on the horse.

At a congressional hearing on copyright rights in 1906, Mark Twain literally shook the participants when he appeared from head to toe in a white linen suit. He is considered the pioneer of a white suit.

Shop "Savile Row" is a Mecca for men's suits. Shops in Savile Row opened in 1846. Known as the "golden mile of tailoring" costumes from these stores are still in great demand and are worth a few thousand dollars
The list of customers of the costume store "Savile Row" includes: Prince Charles, Winston Churchill, Mohammed Ali, Laurence Olivier and Napoleon 3rd.
It was during the prosperity of the store "Savile Row" that the term "bespoke" appeared when the tailors bragged that suits would force their customers to "be spoken for".
Casual Fridays in Japan. If you are tired of your everyday clothes, on Friday you can come to work in "Zentai". That is a latex costume popular in Japan.
64% of men in the world do not have even a single suit.
According to a journal "Vogue" poll, 40% of women believe that men look best in costumes.
The word ‘suit’ derives from the French word 'suite' which means ‘following’ in English.
Croatia neckties were known as cravats (derived from Croatia). Till today, the necktie is the most popular father’s day gift in the world.
A person who loves to collect and hoard neckties is called a grabologist.
Around 4000 BC, Egyptian kings and Pharaohs wore heavy eye makeup.
King Tutankhamun and people during his reign used a green tint, because they believed that the green called the gods of the sun and sky.
The Japanese and the Chinese in 3000 BC. They wore nail polish to denote their higher social status.
Ingredients that people used in ancient China for the manufacture of nail polish, included eggs, gelatin and gum arabic (yellow crystals).
The Romans painted the tops of their heads to hide premature baldness.
200 years ago, people still did not know how to shave properly, and how to deal with the consequences of shaving. Infections and unsanitary conditions eventually led sometimes to death.
A removable collar with 2-3 buttons became a mass trend in the 19th century. The men did not have to change their shirts every day.
Men back in the 18th century not only wore pink(red), but dressed in pink silk suits which were embroidered with flowers. Those men were very powerful and highly respected.
In the early 1900s, young people confidently engaged in sports in pink shirts (the first of which were the Brooks brothers).

From the 1900s, parents bought new clothes of pink color (which was in vogue) for their child. According to statistics, more girls are born, so the girls won a pink color, and now it is believed that pink clothes are the clothes of girls.
Throughout history, men wore many identical types of jewelry that women wear today.
Henry VIII was one notable possessor of precious stones. He was depicted in the famous portrait of Hans Holbein. This picture clearly shows that not only ladies love jewelry but also men.
100 years ago, boys wore dresses, like girls, until they turned 6-7 years old.
If you spend an average of 10 minutes a day on looking in the mirror, it is about 6.5 days a year. Save time.
Petasos" became the prototype of most styles of modern hats. If there was no wind or rain, a hanging from a belt or ribbon Petasos was pushed behind the back.
Scientists also consider medieval gennine as a prototype of modern hats. According to the most widespread version, the high conical hat was invented by Queen of France Isabella of Bavaria in 1395.
Because of the fashion for high hennins (hats) in the castles where they were worn it was necessary to cut a special shape for doorways.
In the XV-XVI centuries, straw hats were popular in Germany and France.
In the time of Charlemagne, there were special customs in wearing headgear: decent people wore the thong (upper part of the hat) feathers of a pheasant and a cock.
In old France green and yellow hats were supposed to show bankruptcy.
The 16th century was known for its "Chaperone" hats. "Chaperone" - hoods with long tails.
Wide-brimmed hats appeared due to unsanitary conditions in European cities and, in particular, due to the tradition of pouring sewage out of the windows almost on the heads of passers-by.
Persian turbans become fashionable in Europe. Famous ladies liked this style for its simplicity and efficiency.
Chepts were used before bedtime and for bathing, so as not to ruffle the hair.
In the second half of the sixteenth century, when Spain dictated European style, berets became popular.

The French musketeers wore felt hats with wide margins and round tops. The edges of the fields were raised and pinned to the tunic, decorated with ribbons, ostrich feathers, buckles of precious metals and stones. They were the elite.
During the reign of Louis XIV, cocked hats became an element of military form, and then spread throughout Europe.
Hats are worn straight, either at an angle or with a strong inclination forward. They say that this shows the mood of a person, or his character.
In Europe, in the Baroque era, ladies wore a Fontane (a lace cap). In became in unfashionable only in 1713.
Aristocrats combined neat hairstyles and simple caps, small lace pins and round Toque hats.
Men in the era of rococo, along with cocked hats, began wearing felt hats and small jockey hats.
For some time, it was possible to wear hats with a mechanism that made the figures of birds or butterflies move.
On the headgear of different times, there were models of sailboats, multi-tower castles, dishes with fruits, swans, mills, bridges, etc.
The ladies wore live flowers on their hats, placed in vases with water, as well as whole compositions, for example, "The expulsion of Adam and Eve from paradise
In 1789 a revolution began in France. As the headdresses began to use a Phrygian cap or ribbon with the colors of the national flag.
By 1789 in France, men wore a castor hat made from high-quality cloth of a very fine workmanship. To make this headdress, beaver or goat fluff was used.
